channel.title: NPR Topics: News
channel.description: NPR news, audio, and podcasts. Coverage of breaking stories, national and world news, politics, business, science, technology, and extended coverage of major national and world events.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 NPR - For Personal Use Only

item.title: Israel strikes U.N-run school in Gaza; a Georgia clinic cares for the uninsured
item.description: Israel launched an airstrike on a U.N.-run school in Gaza as part of a new ground and air operation. A health clinic in Georgia specializes in caring for the uninsured.
item.content:encoded:
Israel launched an airstrike on a U.N.-run school in Gaza as part of a new ground and air operation. A health clinic in Georgia specializes in caring for the uninsured.

(Image credit: Abdel Kareem Hana/AP)
item.dc:creator: Suzanne Nuyen

item.title: Republicans are targeting late-arriving mail ballots ahead of the 2024 election
item.description: Many states, like crucial Nevada, allow mail ballots that are postmarked on or before Election Day to be counted — even if they arrive after Election Day. Republicans say this violates federal law.
item.content:encoded:
Many states, like crucial Nevada, allow mail ballots that are postmarked on or before Election Day to be counted — even if they arrive after Election Day. Republicans say this violates federal law.

(Image credit: John Locher)
item.dc:creator: Ashley Lopez

item.title: Some Democrats say Biden's ban on most asylum-seekers goes too far
item.description: NPR's Michel Martin speaks with Democratic Sen. Alex Padilla of California about President Biden's executive order banning most asylum-seekers from entering the U.S.
item.content:encoded: NPR's Michel Martin speaks with Democratic Sen. Alex Padilla of California about President Biden's executive order banning most asylum-seekers from entering the U.S.
item.dc:creator: Michel Martin

item.title: A heat dome can bring dangerously high temperatures. What is it?
item.description: Much of the Southwest U.S. is experiencing extreme heat this week — with temperatures blazing past 100 degrees. And a phenomenon known as a heat dome is to blame.
item.content:encoded:
Much of the Southwest U.S. is experiencing extreme heat this week — with temperatures blazing past 100 degrees. And a phenomenon known as a heat dome is to blame.

(Image credit: Justin Sullivan)
item.dc:creator: Bill Chappell

item.title: Congressional stock trading law has unintended, but profitable consequence
item.description: The law requiring lawmakers to disclose their stock trades spurred an unintended consequence: a cottage industry with funds modeled on lawmakers' investments. These funds are beating the market.
item.content:encoded:
The law requiring lawmakers to disclose their stock trades spurred an unintended consequence: a cottage industry with funds modeled on lawmakers' investments. These funds are beating the market.

(Image credit: Mark Lennihan)
item.dc:creator: Deirdre Walsh

item.title: The Veepstakes is on. Here are 10 Republicans Trump could pick to be his running mate
item.description: A lot hangs in the balance on who former President Donald Trump chooses as his running mate: the vice presidential nominee might shape the MAGA movement or could woo voters who lean moderate.
item.content:encoded:
A lot hangs in the balance on who former President Donald Trump chooses as his running mate: the vice presidential nominee might shape the MAGA movement or could woo voters who lean moderate.

(Image credit: Julia Nikhinson/AP)
item.dc:creator: Jeongyoon Han

item.title: How to reduce health care’s climate impact? Increase telehealth
item.description: A new study finds telehealth for cancer treatment could make a big difference in reducing carbon footprint of health care. Health care generated 8.5% of U.S. greenhouse gas emissions and there’s a growing effort in medicine to find ways to reduce this impact.
item.content:encoded:
A new study finds telehealth for cancer treatment could make a big difference in reducing carbon footprint of health care. Health care generated 8.5% of U.S. greenhouse gas emissions and there’s a growing effort in medicine to find ways to reduce this impact.

(Image credit: NoSystem images/Getty Images)

item.title: With the veepstakes on, Tim Scott thinks he can deliver the Black votes Trump wants
item.description: Since a failed presidential bid, Sen. Tim Scott has been one of Trump's strongest supporters. Now, as the former president readies to pick a running mate, Scott is focused on winning him Black voters.
item.content:encoded:
Since a failed presidential bid, Sen. Tim Scott has been one of Trump's strongest supporters. Now, as the former president readies to pick a running mate, Scott is focused on winning him Black voters.

(Image credit: Chip Somodevilla/Getty Images)
item.dc:creator: Franco Ordoñez

item.title: The neighbor at the center of the Justice Alito flag controversy speaks out
item.description: Supreme Court Justice Samuel Alito says the reason an upside down U.S. flag was flying at his house, was that his wife put it up because of a beef with a neighbor. We’ll hear from that neighbor.
item.content:encoded: Supreme Court Justice Samuel Alito says the reason an upside down U.S. flag was flying at his house, was that his wife put it up because of a beef with a neighbor. We’ll hear from that neighbor.
item.dc:creator: Tom Dreisbach

item.title: A visit to a clinic in Georgia that provides health care only to the uninsured
item.description: NPR's A Martínez visits Georgia to explore how people without health insurance receive care.
item.content:encoded: NPR's A Martínez visits Georgia to explore how people without health insurance receive care.
item.dc:creator: A Martínez
